THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS. FAIR WARNING!First, I want to get the negative out of the way and in so doing, point out that this film was finished and released in 1952. Perhaps melodrama of this type was the norm, but I came away feeling that this man's immanent death and his reaction to that inevitability was a bit overplayed. There, that is out of the way.I love the way Akira Kurosawa put this together. The film opens on the dull and crushingly boring life of Kanji Watanabe. He is a bureaucrat in the office of public affairs. For thirty years his primary responsibility has been to shift what ever comes to his office to some other department. In short he does nothing. He is a "rubber-stamp" official.Early in the film Watanabe realizes he has terminal cancer. Worse he is not told the truth by his doctor, but finds out from another patient. It is clear he is going to die; and he realizes that he has lived too regimented a life. He has done nothing useful and this, not his impending death, is what really bothers him. The fact that he has managed, for three decades, to waste not only his own time, but the time of others.Fortune is kind to him though. In his despair, he first encounters a novelist who has a penchant for words. This writer, played by Yûnosuke Itô, perfectly expresses what Kanji is going through and applauds his every effort to rectify his wasted life, but it not enough for Kanji.The next day he runs into the youngest coworker in his office. He soon realizes that she has a childlike joy of life and he begins to experience envy and a longing to see life as she does. He eventually frightens her by wanting to spend so much time with her. This is perhaps the best casting done for the entire film, Miki Odagiri as Toyo, delivers such boundless joy and enthusiasm you forget that she's acting.Eventually Kanji finds a purpose for his life and the first three fourths of the film closes on his death. You don't know what he actually accomplished, but you do know by this point that he found a purpose; perhaps now he can die in peace.The last quarter of the film is Kanji's wake and the revelation that he almost single-handedly got this special project completed. His co-workers refuse to believe it at first, but as the wake wears on and the participants become more inebriated, revelations come about that prove that the lowly Watanabi did indeed accomplish his task.It is interestingly done. This could be a very dull story about a small and almost insignificant man and his life. But Kurosawa completely immerses us in Kanji's pain, dismay, and confusion. We become Watanabe. We cannot help but feel very deeply for this character.Just when you would expect the story to tell of Kanji's triumph Kurasawa kills the character and tells the remainder of his story through a series of flash-backs revealing the truth of Kanji's deeds at his funeral. It is almost astounding how many flash-backs there are yet Kurosawa manages to keep the story cohesive and easy to follow.It is a masterwork of story telling, though it seems overly melodramatic by today's standards of cinema.

Most any film with a mind for earnest storytelling can be meaningful and impactful, but even at that not every film digs deep into hearty ruminations on life and modern society. Few are those that speak so directly to such themes as this does. As protagonist Watanabe Kanji learns of his terminal illness and poor prognosis, what ensues is a tableau of many years of life wasted: many years emptily filling a seat in an office, in the process letting all possibility of family life slip away, and having spent so little time living that he doesn't know how to spend money; and a hopeless mire of a bureaucracy, failing to serve the public as intended and becoming wrapped up in its own rules and procedures. At the same time, however it's a tableau of self-realization, and self-discovery: exploring the life that one has missed out on, learning what parts of one's life no longer serve us, making the human connections (general or specific) that one has lacked, finding renewed purpose, and leaving some part of ourselves in the world. And still, for as much as 'Ikiru' leans heavily on these notions, all are woven very naturally into the proceedings with a clear, distinct narrative structure in which they are allowed to reverberate. Through moods dour, sorrowful, lively, heartfelt, and bittersweet, the scene writing is unfailingly vibrant and powerful, with strong characterizations and purposeful dialogue, to impart a firmly compelling, engrossing story. All this comes to bear both where Watanabe is pointedly centered, and where he is simply a part of discussion among other characters. And for as wonderfully smart as the screenplay is, penned by master filmmaker Kurosawa Akira with his regular collaborators Hashimoto Shinobu and Oguni Hideo, the result is unquestionably one of the greatest movies ever made.And it's not just about the writing in and of itself. The tale gives us scenes immediately centering Watanabe, and scenes that do not; flashbacks, and prevalent dialogue; and scenes that directly or indirectly speak to the major themes on hand. Through tones soft and more robust, through both the shortsightedness and near-epiphanies of the bureaucrats, and from seeing Watanabe at his most timid and soft-spoken to his most insistent and determined, the plot progresses in a non-linear manner that is nevertheless bright and flawless. This is in part thanks to the screenplay, yes, but Kurosawa's direction is also impeccable, some of the best he ever achieved, indisputably demonstrating that he was one of the greatest filmmakers to ever live. Countless little moments all throughout are downright brilliant and inspired, a surefire product of Kurosawa's vision; in its blend of more zestful sequences with more sullen ones, and in the flourishes with which some shots and scenes were orchestrated, I am reminded at times of F. W. Murnau's 'Sunrise' of 1927, an artistic masterstroke that itself remains, to this day, one of the best works in all of cinema. Nakai Asakazu's shrewd, dynamic, flavorful cinematography also feeds into this ingenuity, definitely, just as Iwashita Koichi's keen editing helps to deftly shape the picture into the precise, unforgettable form we see. And still, 'Ikiru' wouldn't stand as tall as it does if not for the tremendous acting. All involved are superb, by all means, each finding their time to shine - and mostly within the contemplative last hour. Be that as it may, star Shimura Takashi, an icon of Kurosawa's stable of actors and of Japanese cinema at large, carries the lion's share of the title all by himself. Gentle and haunted as he mostly presents as Watanabe, there is incredible range, nuance, emotional depth, and understated vitality in his performance that is the linchpin of these 143 minutes. I, for one, don't think there can be much arguing that it's one of the single finest performances we've ever seen in the medium.All this is to say nothing of the excellent production design, art direction, costume design, and hair and makeup. Hayasaka Fumio's music is a sparing but welcome complement, helplessly outshone by far by Shimura's timeless performance of "Gondola no uta." From beginning to end and from top to bottom, from those tidbits that we may forget over time to the image that is one of the most recognizable in all of culture, this is a perfect film. That's all there is to it. Some viewers may prefer more outwardly exciting genre fare, but rare are the examples thereof that bear the potency or the staying power that 'Ikiru' does. No matter who you are, everyone needs to see this at least once, and ideally more than once. For my part I've just rewatched for the first time in too many years, and I can truly say that it's even better than I remembered. Scant few are those flicks that demand viewership more than this does, to the point that it almost seems insufficient to say that I give it my recommendation, no matter how high. All I can say is that everyone must make the time for 'Ikiru' at some point in their lives, and time with a movie has scarcely ever been more well spent.

All the Kurosawa movies I have seen yet were either samurai based or mythological. Ikiru is way way way different than all those movies. The things he does in the remaining part of his short life constitutes the movie. Throughout the movie a running motif is that the main protagonist, Watanabe, is like a mummy - that is, the living dead. And he does act extremely decrepit. From what I can tell, he looks to be in his 70s or late 60s, but he plays it like a 90-year-old. Some could say it symbolises how such an ennervated creature can still make a difference. I appreciate the sentiment, but I found it distracting symbolism cramming if that's the case.As for the rest of the movie, it's about a dying man's quest... I don't know what his actual initial objective is, but the byproduct perhaps overshadows whatever he was first trying to accomplish. That is, he discovers the meaning of life. What is the meaning of life, then? You guessed it - cliche as it is - service to other humans, particularly the downtrodden.The journey is relevant. First he tries to burn himself out on temporal pleasures and excitements, but he seems to only feel nostalgic and empty. Then he has a day in the sun with a sprightly young girl. He seems genuinely happy, but I suppose he has to move on, given the age differences and difficulty in maintaining the affections of such a person for such a man. Through this experience he settles into trying to move things through sluggish Japanese governmental bucreacracy to bring the common people some joy. The effect of this is dampened a bit at it's mostly told in narrative by other characters.Thought-provoking? Sure. But I don't buy the message the film is trying to sell and I don't think even the movie itself buys it. It seems to me he was happiest with the girl. Rather than service to unknown masses, then, happiness is to be found in forming strong, joyful bonds with joyous people and trying to make out something of this life together. Unfortunately for Watanabe, his time had passed. Which then takes us to carpe diem?In other words, an interesting and philosophical work, but I wouldn't call it a masterpiece.Honourable Mentions: Jacob's Ladder (1990). Or is there no meaning? Just let things go because that's what you'll have to do eventually anyway.

One of Kurosawa's greatest films, although for several reasons one of the least attractive among his great works for today's audiences.A bureaucrat who has been warming the chair for 30 years and letting the days go by, discovers that he has only a few months to live.As so often in Kurosawa, the structure is very original and surprising, and serves to bring us closer to the story in different and unexpected ways. In addition, Kurosawa is shown as an heir to the best visual cinema of the silent period.The aesthetic is very close, especially in the first half, to the choreographed German expressionism of a Murnau (The last laugh, Sunrise), to the impressive use of depth of field and lighting of Stroheim (Greed), and to the baroque style of the first Welles, or Sternberg (although without his sensuality). The second part is more objective, with an Ozu-esque ceremonial shot brilliantly punctuated with flashbacks. There are plenty of cinematically amazing moments and details of true genius.But there are certainly two aspects, related to each other, that make the film less attractive for today's viewers than other more dynamic and modern works by the author: its expressionism, brilliant as it is, makes it proudly outdated (I'm not saying that as a defect), even for 1952, with its internal rhythm of incisive slowness and its remarkable gestures, ; and the (otherwise inmense and very emotional) performance of Takashi Shimura, which is over the top even in comparison to Jannings in The last laugh. Kurosawa has always liked picturesque and exaggerated theatrical performances, especially in secondary characters (here, the co-workers, for example), but Takashi Shimura is even more overacting than usual, in this case integrating himself into a visual style and a narrative clearly intended.Unforgettable scenes abound: the Faustian night of carousing through various dens culminating in a drunken Takashi Shimura gloomily singing an old carpe diem song; the pivotal moment of the birthday celebration, and the emotional farewell of the protagonist swinging under the snow in the park to whose construction he dedicated all the efforts of the last months of his life.An emotional, great and beautiful film, first class cinema, but one that admires us more than entertains us, that at times seems unnecessarily slow and repetitive, but not to be missed.

The supporting cast is equally brilliant, creating an authentic atmosphere. The camera angles and lighting are masterfully done, adding to the perfection of the film.In conclusion, Ikiru stands as one of the greatest movies ever made. I would give it a perfect 10/10 and wholeheartedly recommend it.

Based loosely on Tolstoy's "Death of Ivan Ilych", this is a tale of the tragedy and redemption of a man whom few directors would dare featuring: a faceless, lifeless bureaucrat. Takashi Shimura plays said bureaucrat with stolid grace, never overplaying the physical and psychic pain that defines him for the first third of the film. He is estranged from his family, his employers, his life, until an improbable encounter with a lively, lovely former coworker and a pet rabbit. At last he sees how his life, so close to its end, can mean something.I highly recommend the 2-disc Criterion set, which includes two documentaries on Kurosawa's life and work, and a commentary track by Kurosawa scholar Stephen Prince, who's done similar work for Criterion's releases of "Throne of Blood", "Seven Samarai", "Ran" and several others. My lone complaint is with the transfer; typically a strength of Criterion's classic discs. While most scenes are clear, bright and unblemished, others have long stretches of vertical scratches and faded black tones. Knowing the attention to detail that other, even older, films have enjoyed, it's a bit jarring to see.

There are the main themes here that resonate all through--trying to live a life with meaning, and then trying to rectify your life when you realize you've failed. It's a movie about redemption, but the focus is on the struggle to find that redemption, not the feel-good aftermath.It has to be noted that the filming--the cinematography--is astonishing. Sometimes this is what carries the film, as in the moments in the middle where the main character and his new friend and doing the night life in Tokyo.The main character, Kanji Watanabe, may sometimes play the worn out old man too excessively, grunting his way through important moments, but in the big picture that's what this is trying to figure out--how someone at that lowest of lows can find a way forward in his remaining days. Of course, the layers of administration in the municipal government are a key character of their own, playing against the needs of many of the characters and defining those needs for others.The final scenes, extended beautifully, that show a funeral and the men (mostly) interacting is quite humbling. The writing does get contrived here--we know what's happening before it happens--but the overall point is great and has a lot of details between the larger arc.Yes, a kind of great film. And yes, I suppose it works better for people who are older, but who knows?

Nicholson in "The Bridge On the River Kwai" (1957). I find "Ikiru" to be a rare film. One amongst so many great classics from the 40s-60s that has a really special touch to it. One that just can't be replicated.You follow Kanji Watanabe around in his last few months, a man seemingly hopeless and confused. Clearly distraught, the man searches for any sort of purpose and something that he can take to the grave with dignity.While the premise is straightforward enough, it's the execution of the film that obviously makes it so great. Watanabe does not have to say much for you to understand the pain of the dilemma he faces. It's actually a really quiet film, despite the rowdiness of the first half when he goes about the town with the novelist and Toyo. That's one of the many beautiful things about the movie. The underlying atmosphere of desperation and hope are present even when it's not the topic of discussion.Sometimes in movies, it's hard to take away a lesson or any moral value that it might have. And sometimes films hardly have any at all. "Ikiru" could not be further from this. It is so honest, so forthright in its intentions. It shows how every day is a gift. It tells us that life is a blessing and it moves by way too quickly. It demonstrates how there is beauty in the smallest of things, from a tasty meal to a gorgeous sunset. It lets us know that acts of kindness from the heart are one of the most rewarding and tranquil parts of life.This movie will move you unlike most. There is something very, very special about it. Akira Kurosawa has so many great classics under his belt, but this is his best movie, and it's one of my favorites of all time.10/10.

The real question of this story is: if you knew you were going to die, what would you do? Would you spend your last days doing everything you wanted to do any form of pleasure you can imagine, or would you do something importance, something that would actually mean something.An old man (Takashi Shimura) named Kenji is dying of cancer and feels his whole life has been wasted. For the past 30 years he's been working at Tokyo City Hall behind a desk accomplishing absolutely nothing, mainly just stamping papers with his rubber stamp and warming his chair.When he does find out he has cancer in the beginning of the film, he simply stops going to work and one day meets a stranger (who does a terrific job with his role) in a bar and in a conversation he says that he has money but doesn't know how to spend it for sheer entertainment. The stranger has pity on the man but at the same time envy since he doesn't just kill himself, but faces the facts of life and so of course he helps the old man have a good time but with his money as they go out on a night of night clubs, women and booze.Akira Kurosawa is one of my personal favorite directors and has many masterpieces but this doesn't exactly rank among those masterpieces like "Ran", "Throne of Blood", "Yojimbo" and the forgotten gem "The Bad Sleep Well". But that doesn't mean that this isn't a good film because in reality it's a great film, and the strongest point of this film is the simple but brilliant script as it tells us to appreciate life and the beauty of it, while we have it, hence the title of the film, "Ikiru" which means "To Live".One thing I didn't like about this film is the way the old man talks throughout the film; as if he can barley speak and you can barley make out what he is saying. But then again that is his role, moping around with this performance, you really believe that this man is dying of cancer and is truly upset with himself for not "living" his life all these years. One of his co-workers even tells to him over lunch that everyone has a nickname at the office and his was "The Mummy". He pauses for a minute and she thinks she has offended him but he reassures her that she hasn't in-fact; she has named him perfectly as he realizes that's what his life has been ever since his beloved wife has left him 30 years ago.Kenji feels that the worse part isn't dying; he feels that he has wasted his whole life and doesn't want to die before he does something of importance, meaning he wants to live his last days and not just exist as he has been doing all his life. He feels that he has been dead for a long time now but is just realizing it now when it's too late.There is a great moral to this story and a novelist in this film says it best with this beautiful and unforgettable quote: "How tragic that man can never realize how beautiful life is until he is face to face with death."

This Japanese film was released in 1952 after the end of World War 2 in the Pacific. This was six years into the American occupation and transformation of Japan into a Democratic, Capitalistic nation.I found it mesmerizing having been born on a USA military base in Japan in 1948 to parents from Pittsburgh PA, then moving from base to base in Japan until the age of seventeen and a half, as the occupation downscaled.It depicts how readily the Americanization of Japan was occurring with baseball, nightclubs, music, and youthful behavior.The entrenched, autocratic bureaucratization of Japanese government is revealed. This is the fictional tale of a midlevel bureaucrat who had been grieving the death of his wife for thirty years thus existing not living. His transformation, due to a life-changing experience, led to his win for good thus exemplifying the potential for change in a corrupted government.The film demonstrates how guilt and ancestry devotion has long played a role in Japanese society.

Kanji Watanabe discovers that he has cancer, and tries to seek some sort of meaning in his final days, he becomes aware that he's operated as a cog in the giant domestic machinery, and fights against the system.I've been working my way through The Kurosawa films, and thus far I've been impressed with the lot, I'll be honest, I expected a Samurai film, and when it became apparent that that wasn't the case either, I thought it may have been a mystery, it wasn't that either, instead it turned out to be a rather intimate, absorbing character study.It shows that despite being essentially part of a machine, Kanji has a very human side, only he realises it too late.This film moved me to tears on occasion, it had me laughing, it certainly had be captivated for the whole running time. That moment where Kanji explains what's happening to his son, it was phenomenal.I am learning more about Kurosawa with each film I watch, but I must admit, this one threw me totally off guard, it wasn't what I was expecting, it further enhances my realisation that Kurosawa was a genius.Remember all work and no play! There's a really meaningful message in this film.

With brutal honesty I admit that despite loving Japanese cinema that love hasn't extended much beyond Ghibli and some early Manga (Akira) but I've read quite a few Japanese novels and I've had the pleasure of travelling around Japan for 5 weeks.There's something wholly cleansing about the childlike honesty and purity of Japanese culture that's an antidote to the excesses of western consumerism. This heartfelt tale Watanabe and his coming to terms with the vagaries that confront him will enrich your life.Kurasawa is a proper film maker, unapologetically hegemonic and all the better for it. If you're sick of Hollywood watch this.

"Ikiru" is the story of one man--Kanji Watanabe (Takashi Shimura), a government bureaucrat with a boring and meaningless job. He keeps his head down and never questions the status quo or his place as a cog in the machinery of local government.When he realizes he has little time left to live, he thinks of death, then the choices he has made in life. He is absent from work for the first time in thirty years, lost in reverie and unable to cope with what he sees as his failure to achieve anything of value.The viewer, guided by a voice over, knows Watanabe is having an existential meltdown, and wonders how this character can ever find redemption in his own eyes.He tries a variety of new experiences (shades of Ferris Bueller). But he still feels a failure. Eventually, he returns to his job and attempts a new strategy."Ikiru" is a tribute to those who get things done. Other films have celebrated the kind man ("It's a Wonderful Life"), the principled man ("12 Angry Men" or "To Kill a Mockingbird"); "Ikiru" celebrates the man with a vision and the determination to carry it out, especially in the face of bureaucracy.Director Kurosawa called "Ikiru" his greatest work, perhaps because he valued its universal themes. Shimura--a Kurosawa favorite--acts with minimal expression. Watanabe is a sponge soaking up his environment. He is a blank slate upon which we paint our own faces and confront our own truths.This is a film that deserves to be seen.

"Ikiru" is undoubtedly a masterpiece that showcases a mastery of defining the boundaries between life and death; there is no need to debate this. However, it also documents this characteristic by prompting the audience to embark on a quest for "judgment." When you see this film, you cannot help but reconsider the reasons for your life (or living). The pivotal moments in our lives, guided by right or wrong choices, become unavoidable to recall. Although this may lead us towards disappointment and despair from one perspective, it also opens the door to questioning whether it is ever too late. "Ikiru" conveys the message that preventing the monotony of a perspective that trivializes details is within our control, reminding us not to become mere "living dead." It emphasizes the necessity of living a life open to risks.

Kurosawa gently asks, with a soft but firm tap on the shoulder, "So... what are you doing with your life?" What begins as a bureaucratic drama turns into a surprisingly tender, ironic, and life-affirming punch to the gut. With heartbreaking simplicity, dry humor, and a deep undercurrent of sadness, the film proves that meaning isn't found in grand gestures-sometimes it's just a swing set in the snow. Quiet, cheeky, and devastating in the best way. By the end, it doesn't preach; it simply sits with you long after the film is over. Probably my favorite Akira Kurosawa film.

I've recently dived into the history of one of the most amazing, prolific, and legendary Japanese film men of all time: Akira Kurosawa! I've started his filmography with this movie, Ikiru (To Live), and what a touching film it was!Mr. Kanji Watanabe is an apparently ordinary, uneventful man, having been working the same job for the past 30 years. Nothing ever really happens for, or to him in his life...until one day, he receives an unexpected medical diagnoses: stomach cancer! With less than one year to live, Kanji summons up his inner desire to try and enjoy something truly memorable, make as many memories as possible, and perhaps leave something behind for everyone to remember him by, once he ascends to Heaven.I was very engaged and focused with Kanji's predicament, watching as he tries to find some excitement and joy to satisfy him before he dies, telepathically encouraging him to not give up. He meets two different people who attempt to help him find some excitement. One person is an eccentric writer, but he mostly just takes Kanji to bars and clubs, which don't seem to be satisfying him. The other person, is a woman named Toyo, to whom Kanji finds himself attracted to. I personally liked their chemistry and relationship much better; their interactions seemed to be much more eventful, and Kanji seemed to be engaging more and more in life each time he and Toyo meet. Toto eventually shares a fun fact or two with Kanji, and Kanji reveals his cancer to her. I'm glad the two didn't actually become lovers, just friends, because friends are usually one of the best things to cling to if you soon will be leaving the land of the living, as is the love of family, though Kanji's family don't show too much love and support for him, partially because they are unaware of his cancer, but also because they are fixated on inheriting Kanji's money and other belongings. Had Kanji and Toyo became lovers, I suspect that may have created more conflict between the two, and that conflict may have spread outward, and affected Kanji's family and employees, whom he works with.What a gentle, moving, touching, and adventurous movie Ikiru was! I enjoyed it a lot! Take this movie as a reminder to always embrace and enjoy life the best you can! Make as many friends and memories as possible, and most of all, take the love your family and friends give you, and give your own love to them, for none of us know when exactly, our time will come, to leave life, and enter eternal life...

The remarkable Takashi Shimura takes center stage in this bittersweet tale of a minor official whose life in microcosm is the drudgery of maintaining the status quo. There are lessons to be learned here, for all of us must (at some point in our lives) learn "to live..."

Any praise one can give to Ikiru is an understatement. In a filmography composed of masterpieces, I find Ikiru to be one of the most heartfelt and poetic works from the master Kurosawa.Takashi Shimura is Kanji Watanabe a committed bureaucrat in post war Japan. For decades there was just one constant in life, work. In an instant this reality is shattered as Watanabe discovers he little time remaining. And thus Watanabe sets out to live life, to discover the intricate beauties of the people and world around him.Shimura gives the performance of a lifetime. He disappears completely into the role. Every action, every expression, is portrayed with so mach heart I cannot imagine the film without him. This also holds true for the rest of the cast. Each character is given such life and unique subtleties that work well off of Shimura. Kurosawa's direction here is some of his finest, the film being so beautifully shot and composed. And the end, so heartbreaking yet so hopeful. The film is truly art in every sense of the world and stands as one of the finest films ever made.

This is the kind of movie you watch to reinvigorate a love for life. Kurosawa's most intimate and most moving work, especially when you consider other works where he lets his nihilistic views take center stage. Just a powerful movie with a stunning Lead performance.

Over the years I think I've devoted nearly half a day of my valuable time watching and re-watching this multi-layered masterpiece. One of its main messages to me is : what would I do in a similar position to the protagonist of the story? Most of us belong to the wage slave class and are in work roles utterly useless to the greater humanity, what would we do if told we had a few months to live (disregarding the fact that even 100 years/1200 months is an infinitesimal fraction of a geological eye-blink)?Watanabe-san is the buck-passing rubber-stamping Section Chief of the Public Affairs Dept. in City Hall, never having had a day off in 30 years until told (in a roundabout way) that he has terminal stomach cancer. He goes AWOL, does a little drinking and flirting and finally comes to the conclusion that he needs to leave something constructive behind him. It all unfolds in Kurosawa's usual inimitable fluid story-telling style  he left behind a beautiful b&w Japanese film languidly but constructively dealing with terminal illness that can still hook people in to this day. Favourite bits: In the bar where Watanabe-san mournfully groans out his requested song Life Is Brief to the suddenly electrified patrons  and us; the stark contrast between him and his confused state and the young and healthy flibbertigibbet he spends a few days with; the flashbacks of him doggedly pursuing his pet project at City Hall; the culmination of everything on the playground swing at 11:00 pm on a snowy night. No good doing that here  the park would be full of losers instead of winners like him.To the impatient I suppose it would be pretty slow at times, but in the hands of this particular Master I wouldn't have minded it lasting another hour. Beautiful, poignant, elegant, thoughtful, wistful, powerful  and imho not Kurosawa's best either! In other words, a film other directors would die for.

Kanji Watanabe is a widowed bureaucrat as the city's public affairs section chief. The bureaucratic machine has ground any ambition out of him. He has slowly climbed up the ladder by doing nothing and therefore doing nothing wrong. He discovers that he has stomach cancer and probably only six months to live. He is lost. He doesn't go to work and takes out his life savings. His son is shocked. He spends a wild night with a writer but he feels empty. He spends some time with a young exuberant female staffer. Eventually he decides to make a difference through his work.This is a movie that makes one think about one's own life. It is a compelling everyman movie. The last third isn't quite as compelling without Kanji. That part does have a point to make but it could have been done in a shorter way. This is a Kurosawa classic and an important one.

Kanji Watanabe, a bureaucrat workaholic, tries to find his purpose in the world after discovering tgst he suffers from terminal cancer.Master Kurosawa's most emotional and moving film, and his best work besides the samurai theme. I don't have that kind of time."

Probably 黒澤明 (Akira Kurosawa)'s most realistic take on his humanism; one should try to do as much good as he/she can, but should also expect resistance at every turn in this endeavour. Akira Kurosawa, the Japanese director more famously known for his epic samurai stories, takes us into the depths of post-war Japan in this very human story of a government official who discovers he has terminal cancer and only six months to live. With this new found information, he decides to start living his life, something he neglected to do for the past thirty years when he never missed a day of work.As the story progresses, we learn more as to why our protagonist is in such a conservative state of mind. This, in turn, propels him to take up a crusade for the people of the city and help them and change their life for the better. This goes to show the most human side of Kurosawa we have ever seen. The character of Watanabe is handled very delicately, never condescending or preaching. He is simply a man who struggles with meaning and definition of his own life but wants to change that forever.It is in this context that Ikiru also has its failures. The final third act of this film is mostly a group of men sitting around talking about Watanabe while drinking plenty of sake and getting very drunk. TO me, this scene dragged on for way to long and was in fact mostly unnecessary. There were also some other scenes that didn't fit too well with the narrative, but they were far and few in between.So, to be honest, this is a real underrated treasure from Kurosawa. And even though it doesn't have the sheer willpower or amazement from his other works, this is definitely a testament to humans and the remarkable changes we can make by putting our mind to something.

Senior bureaucrat Kanji Watanabe (Takashi Shimura) searches for meaning and purpose in life after finding out that he has only a few months to live. Kurosawa's film is a beautiful, sad masterpiece and Takashi Shimura is excellent as the soft-spoken man who belatedly realises that his life has become meaningless. The film is structured episodically as first Watanabe and a dissipated writer (Yunosuke Ito) explore the seamier side of Tokyo's nightlife, finding no answer in there, he spends time with a vivacious young co-worker (Miki Odagiri) whose joy in life he admires but ultimately cannot be part of, and finally the development of the children's park, in which he finally finds solace and meaning. Kurosawa expertly switches from linear narrative to a flashback structure halfway through the film, and viewers move from Watanabe's perspective to those of his bureaucratic co-workers, as they drink sake at his wake and discuss the changes in the man over his dying days. The scenes of the increasingly drunk men reminiscing are similar to the director's earlier classic Rashomon (1950), as each man tells an aspect of the story from a different perspective. Kurosawa also uses the film to skewer a stultified Japanese bureaucracy, especially self-serving public 'servants' and their sycophants, the wasteful redundancy and resulting zealous turf-guarding, and the endless, worthless 'busywork'. The final scene of Watanabe, serene and satisfied, is beautiful. A flawless, timeless classic.

The only film Akira Kurosawa made between 1948 and 1965 that did not include Toshiro Mifune in any way, Ikiru is one of the most tenderly human, aesthetically beautiful, and deeply moving films I've ever seen. I labeled it my favorite Kurosawa many years ago, long before I'd seen all of his film (I still haven't as of this writing), and yet I seriously doubt that any film will topple it from that spot. This is one of the pinnacles of cinema, a work of such unbridled and touching emotion that faces death squarely and demands a chance to make an impact on the world. The impact may be small, no larger than a small city park for children, but the impact will remain.The story is about Kanji Watanabe (Takashi Shimura), a thirty-year veteran of the Tokyo city bureaucracy given the anodyne prognosis of a mild stomach ulcer that he knows is actually a cover for stomach cancer, an effective death sentence that gives him no more than a year to live (a common practice in Japanese medicine at the time was to lie about certain terminal diseases to patients in order to save them grief). Understanding his fate, he's left facing the life he's led, and he realizes how little he's actually lived.This film is both deceptively simple and marvelously complex, and the way the complexity arises is in its structure. There are two major sections of the film that are dominated by flashbacks, the opening third and the final third. The opening third's flashbacks serve a specific purpose in that it is Watanabe reflecting back on the failings of his life, in particular around his son Mitsuo (Nobuo Kaneko). Watanabe's wife died when Mitsuo was only a small child, and Watanabe reflects back on key moments from Mitsuo's childhood when he failed his son. There was the car ride to the funeral of the boy's mother, where he failed to properly console him, a baseball game when the boy was older where Watanabe could not bring himself to cheer on the boy after he had ran into a pickle and been picked off, and Mitsuo's going in for an appendectomy that Watanabe finds an excuse to leave. Combined with his meritorious work in the public affairs department of the city government where Watanabe failed to accomplish a single thing over three decades, Watanabe feels lost with only a few months to live, a mountain of savings from a life of frugality, and nothing to live for.So, he tries to live for himself. He disappears from work for a week and starts drinking in little dive sake bars, eventually running across a writer (Yunosuke Ito) who listens to Watanabe's tale, only able to tell it to a complete stranger, and the duo go out on the town. What follows is a string of bars, dancing, and hat purchasing as the writer shows Watanabe the selfish side of life. He's ultimately unfulfilled by it all, though, with a crushing moment as Watanabe requests the song "Gondola no Uta" from a piano player and sings the lyrics, his mouth hardly opening, and in such a sad way that it stops everyone around him to observe. Finding this empty, Watanabe, the next morning, comes across one of his underlings on the street. This is Toyo (Miki Odagiri), the young woman in his office who has come to him to get him to sign off on her resignation from the civil service. She can't stand the inaction, the monotony, and the lack of interest that accompanies a life in the Japanese bureaucracy.Instead of simply stamping her resignation (the wrong form, he informs her before dutifully stamping the form that's in front of him like he always does) and letting her go, he invites her out to a day on the town, showering her with presents like stockings, lunch, and a time at the carnival. For over a week, he keeps doing this, even after her resignation at city hall has gone through and she's started working in a toy manufacturing plant assembling mechanical hopping bunnies, and her patience grows thin. His selfless act of showering her with attention, presents, and nights out on the town has become unsatisfying to her, and the news is crushing to Watanabe. He wants to live in his final months. He wants to live through someone else, and when Toyo pushes him away he gets an idea. He shows up at work for the first time in two weeks, dashing the hopes of advancement of his second in command Sub-Section Chief Ono (Kamatari Fujiwara) with his mere presence, he finds the first request on his large stack of papers, a request for the paving over of an open and fetid water source in a slum to be replaced by a playground for children, and he's off to make it happen.Then the movie does something unexpected. It jumps forward five months to his wake. He's accomplished his goal of building the playground, credit denied to him by the Deputy Mayor (Nobuo Nakamura), seen the opening ceremony, and then died, succumbing to his illness, that very night, alone on the playground. What erupts next is an extended debate on what Watanabe did, how responsible he was for the construction of the playground, and the effect he's had on those around him. This is the final fifty minutes of the film, and it's marvelous. With a more straightforward telling of the story, we'd have Kurosawa stringing us along with the ins and outs of the bureaucracy while forming tension around whether the playground will get constructed or not. By skipping ahead, Kurosawa completely changes the focus. There's no longer any tension around the material construction but a refocus on the effects of Watanabe's embrace of life on those around him.It begins with the Deputy Mayor announcing that he should be given the full credit for the playground's construction, not Watanabe, and that his disrespecting of Watanabe at the opening ceremony by placing him in the back of the crowd was completely justified. All of the section chiefs nod in approval, along with their subordinates, but the Deputy Mayor has to leave after a crowd of women arrive, tearfully placing incense and flowers before Watanabe's picture, obviously giving him credit for saving them and their children from the fetid water that had plagued their homes. With the Deputy Mayor and his section chiefs gone, the subordinates begin the real debate where they piece together the final few months from their individual interactions with Watanabe to discover that it was his dedication above and beyond the limits of his station that led to this good work, that he was driven by his stomach cancer that they decide he must have known about, and that they will all endeavor to become like him in their daily lives. This, of course, does not happen, for the new Public Affairs Section Chief, Ono, sends the next group of petitioners at the desk on the same runaround that the ladies who wished to have the park built had gone through.There's a remarkable mixture of cynicism and humanism apparent here with the grinding down of the bureaucracy removing the basics of human decency from those within it, but, at the same time, the finding of power within the individual to make a difference, no matter how small. Watanabe went through his life alone, even in the end he relied on no one else to give him solace. He worked to make his life matter, and the final shots of Watanabe, perhaps his ghost, swinging in the playground, and singing "Gondola no Uta" are touching. He will be forgotten. His works will endure for at least a while longer.The tender humanity in Watanabe's journey from mummy (Toyo's nickname for him) to someone who lives, even for a short time, is wonderfully laid out and executed by Kurosawa, his cowriters (Shinobu Hashimoto and Hideo Oguni), and, in particular, Takashi Shimura. Shimura was a very good actor in general, and he had a distinctive face, especially when he was meant to look sad, pulling his lower face in and pronouncing his lips, and he gives Watanabe a deep sense of loss, resolve, and emotion as he faces his final days with determination. It's also another example of Kurosawa's remarkable eye, providing marvelous compositions from beginning to end from two people talking in a rundown sake bar to Watanabe facing down goons in a hallway to the final shot of Watanabe on that swing. The aesthetics support the narrative, never calling attention to themselves, always feeling appropriate, and very often just being beautiful to look at.Ikiru is a masterpiece. It's one of my favorite films. It is a towering achievement of humanism and emotion. I adore this movie.

Like many other people who have had the benefit of watching this fine piece from Kurosawa, I was touched and found that alot that goes on is still true in our society. At the centre of "Ikiru" are the massive issue of mortality and the thoughtful, poignant performance by Takashi Shimura, but Kurosawa's direction also managed to find moments of humour in the oddest places. I've seen a few of Kurosawa's films, and while I agree he's a good filmmaker, I've never been truly captivated. "Ran" is a good film, but it's basically "King Lear" in Japan and told in a stylized and painfully slow manner; "Yojimbo" is a good action film with plenty of violence, but that's it; "Seven Samurai" is good and very well-made, but it's also very slow, bloated and predictable; "Rashomon" has a very well-thought-out mystery, but it's overly complicated.Well... with this film, Kurosawa finally won my admiration. Never before had a film by this director captivated and touched me in this way. The director, who also wrote the screenplay, offers us a truly moving story about an elderly civil servant who discovers he has cancer and will die within a few months. Far from being a depressing film about the inexorability of death or human ephemerality, the film philosophizes a lot (yes, Kurosawa loves to make his films a marathon lasting hours, and this one is even short) about the meaning of life and the mark we leave on the world. The old man finally realizes that he spent decades in a room cluttered with paperwork doing nothing and, therefore, his existence was a waste of time. Thus, he begins to seek new meaning for his final months. The film is full of incredible moments, like the one where the bureaucrats vow to follow his example knowing, as we also know, that such words are the vain babble of drunks filled with self-pity, or the tension between father and son when the inheritance is threatened by the man's unpredictable behavior.Anyone who knows Japan at all knows that, in general, the Japanese are perfectionists and meticulous, used to dedicating themselves 110% to whatever they do, and raised within a society that cultivates extreme, almost servile, humility and respect for hierarchies and "institutional" ways. Unlike us, Latins, they never seek shortcuts to circumvent bureaucracy or overcome obstacles. The Japanese, even more than obeying the law, love to follow directives and do everything by the book. And the director shows us how this, in a way, has created a public administration paralyzed by the interests or disinterest of powerful individuals, cluttered with useless paperwork and officials who push files from department to department instead of giving solutions. Those employees could also be from a multinational corporation or any other service provider: they are people who do nothing, who waste their lives and force others to do the same while they wait for their requests to be solved. They are parasites. Ultimately, the film's message is the good old "carpe diem": the best way to give meaning to our lives is to seek our own happiness and that of those around us, and not waste time on things that can be resolved with a little goodwill and dedication from each person.The performances by Takashi Shimura and Miki Odagiri are magnetic, and both actors deserve congratulations on their work. The film boasts very well-done cinematography, excellent sets and good costumes. As I said, it is a bit too long, it's possible to make a cut version of about an hour and fifty minutes without losing much of anything important. The film also has almost no soundtrack, and this, combined with its length and the occasional deadpan, can dull the audience. This time I handled it well, but Kurosawa has this problem.
Now I am completely and irreversibly depressed about the state of modern man and the enveloping bureaucracy.  Hopeless.Just the same, a very beautiful film.  Unmatched in its genre.

Ikiru is a film that lingers in the mind long after the credits roll. I had the opportunity to watch it on a rainy afternoon, which added to the somber yet reflective mood of the film. From the moment Kanji Watanabe, played masterfully by Takashi Shimura, learns of his terminal illness, I felt an immediate connection to his plight. The stark contrast between his monotonous bureaucratic life and the vibrant emotions he begins to experience was striking.What struck me most was how Kurosawa beautifully encapsulates the essence of life's fleeting nature. Watanabe's journey from a lifeless cog in a bureaucratic machine to a man seeking meaning was both heartbreaking and inspiring. I found myself laughing and crying in equal measure, especially during the poignant moments with his son. The scene where Watanabe attempts to share his diagnosis is a gut-wrenching reminder of the emotional distance that often exists in familial relationships. It resonated with me deeply, as it made me reflect on my own connections with loved ones.The film's exploration of bureaucracy is another layer that I found compelling. The absurdity of the system that Watanabe navigates is both frustrating and humorous. It's a critique of how society often prioritizes rules over human connection, and that struck a chord with me. I could feel the weight of his realization that he had spent so much of his life in a soulless routine, and it made me question my own daily choices.As the film progresses, Watanabe's quest to leave a meaningful legacy becomes a powerful narrative. The moment he decides to build a park for children is a turning point that filled me with hope. It's a reminder that it's never too late to make a difference, and that small acts of kindness can ripple through the lives of others. The imagery of him on the swing, a symbol of reclaiming joy, is etched in my memory.While the final act shifts towards a more political commentary, I found it necessary to complete the story arc. It serves as a reminder that even in our most personal struggles, we are often entangled in larger societal issues. Kurosawa's ability to weave these themes together is a testament to his genius.Ikiru is not just a film; it's an experience that challenges you to reflect on your own life choices and the legacy you wish to leave behind. It's a gentle nudge to embrace the beauty of existence, even in the face of inevitable.

I watched "Ikiru" for the second time after seeing its remake "Living" (2022, Oliver Hermanus). The pitfall therefore is that I compare the two films in the wrong order. I shall try to avoid this pitfall by not comparing the two films at all (or at least as little as possible). All I would like to say about it is that "Living" is a very faithfull remake of "Ikiru" and still a good film in its own right. This indicates that "Ikiru" must be a great film, and this indication is true.The story is about the bureaucrat Watanabe (played by Takashi Shimura) who is diagnosed with cancer at the beginning of the movie. He has only a few month to live. His first reaction is to take a walk on the wilde side for the first time in his lfe. He soon realises that this only leads to a shallow satisfaction and decides to spend his last months creating a neighborhood playground.I will make some remarks about each phase of the storyline.We are first introduced to Watanabe the bureaucrat. The bureacracy is really outrageous. Piles of papers are shuffled around, collecting a lot of (apparently necessary) stamps. The bureaucrats are disappearing after there own piles, citizens are sent from one department to another. After watching this part of the film you know that the concept of meaningless jobs was not discovered by David Graeber.The diagnosis scene is I think a bit dated. The doctors don't tell Watanabe the bad news but they try to comfort him. However a man in the waiting room had Wanabe told which words doctors usually use to wrap bad news in, and these doctors use exactly the same words. This is probably the scene in which "Living" differs the most from its original. It is still a fascinating scene though. When Watanabe leaves the hospital the film is completely silent to convey the extent to which Watanabe is shocked by the news. Only when a truck passes by there is sound again.The desire to walk on the wild side is partly prompted by the arduous relationship between Watanabe and his son. He has heard a conversation between his son and his girlfriend indicating that they are most of all interested in his inheritance. A few flashbacks however show that this arduous relationship is not only due to the son.Watanabe may want to walk on the wild side, he has no idea how. A novelist comes to his aid, acting (in his own words) as a sort of benificent Mephistopheles. Together they visit gambling palaces, dance halls and the red light district. In the red light district scene there is practically no nude, but still this scene is more erotic than the equivalent one in "Living". The most moving scene of this part of the film is however a drunken Watanabe singing an old song in a dance hall, reminding not only himself but all visitors of their mortality.The transition from the wild side to good deeds is set in motion by a young colleague from the office. She has resigned because the work was dull and monotonous. She has put a meaningful job ahead of career perspective and causes Watanabe to rethink his own decisions thirty years ago.The good deeds part of the story is told as a flash back. The colleague bureacrats of Watanabe visit his funeral and talk about his strange behaviour of the last months. They only begin to understand when they are drunk, and prefer to forget this understanding when they are sober again.There are many beautiful shots in "Ikiru". I already mentioned a few (Watanabe leaving the hospital, the drunken Watanabe singing in a dance hall) but the most famous is without any doubt the shot of Watanabe happily on the swing of the playground he fought so hard for.There are many films about love, but there are only a few films about dying. By dying I do not mean dying the quick way (such as in the shoot out of a Western), but dying the slow way (such as in "Ikiru"). But don't be fooled, "Ikiru" translates as "to live". It is not about a man dying too soon, it is about a man starting living too late."Ikiru" is a film that makes you think. Yes Watanabe is an outrageous bureaucrat, but what about me? Maybe I'm also postponing good intentions until after my retirement?Akira Kurosawa is most well known for his samourai films such as "Rashomon" (1950) and "Seven samourai" (1954). He has however also made very good movies in other genres. Apart from "Ikiru" (1952) I like to mention "Red beard" (1965) and "Dersu Uzala" (1975).In the "old man looks back on his life" genre "Ikiru" is only equaled in my opinion by "Wild strawberries" (1957, Ingmar Bergman).

Like most Akira Kurosawa films, Ikiru is better the second time around, and I remember thinking it was pretty great then first time. It's certainly the director's most emotional movie, but it's not overly sentimental. It strikes this perfect balance between being broadly moving but also realistic. There are moments that hit hard, but it never feels like it's overdoing things, and the final act - though there are many points at which it could - never ventures into something overly sweet. I appreciate that balancing act more than ever. It feels warm and sad all at once, and I left feeling both inspired and a little despondent, which isn't something you can say about most films.It's long, and a tiny bit slow, but I'll also give it this: I was tired tonight and watched this in a dark theater, but I never came close to nodding off. That's always a good sign, especially for something that's relatively grounded and patiently paced. I'd forgotten how well this was filmed, too. Even though Kurosawa is capturing rather ordinary sights and locations, there are still some really awe-inspiring moments of camerawork - less flashy than Seven Samurai, but still. It's not as flashy a movie, but it still has that visual punch.It was also good to see this in a cinema that was pretty much filled to capacity with people rocking up to see a 70-year-old Japanese film that's 140 minutes long on a Tuesday night. This can only be a good thing, and is worth celebrating, even if it's not directly tied to the film's quality itself.Also, a line from this ran through my mind as I was driving home. Someone in the lane in front of me was going a bit too slow. I started to feel myself getting angry, but then I remembered the main character in this, faced with his mortality, saying, "I don't have the time to hate anyone," resisting the urge to get angry and instead opting to just persevere. And that calmed me down. It's a silly and small example of the film sticking with me, but I hope to keep some of the lessons here in mind. There's a simple message at the heart of this film, but it's one worth repeating, if just to serve as a reminder about the fragility of life and the necessity of standing up to passive negativity and bureaucracy (a word I hate so much, partly because I can never spell it. Any movie that critiques bureaucracy as much as Ikiru is cool in my book).

Sometimes films released more than 50 years ago don't have the same impact they once did. Well, that's not the case at all for Ikiru, one of Akira Kurosawa's first universally praised hits.Ikiru tells the story of a man out of time. A bureaucratic man who has worked the same job for decades and can't seem to find any purpose in his work or life in general. That is, until he finds out he has terminal stomach cancer. What follows is a coming of age story for a middle aged man who does his best to leave an impact on the world he will inevitably leave. With one of these types of stories, it all comes down to execution. The only way to make a film like this leave you with a particularly effective message is to have a filmmaker like Kurosawa. For the most part, I did go through the emotions the film wanted me to. It's also a story that lends itself to being more relatable the older you get. It's not easy for a 23-year-old guy like me to understand what Watanabe goes through in Ikiru, but it may be something that I relate to more as I get older.I found this film to be especially inspiring from his co-workers perspective. No one at the office does anything of value it seems, and it's only until after Watanabe takes a leave of absence and goes on a journey of self-discovery that they feel like they need to do something as well. The film shifts from Watanabe's story to his friends & families' story about half way through. I found each part to be interesting in its own right, but watching the people he cares about look back on his life and the impact he seemed to have made was some powerful stuff. The lessons and themes in the film are important ones. Pleasure is not living. Don't always do things for others or to please others, make sure you're taken care of as well. And most importantly, life is brief, make of it as you wish.+Poignant+Kurosawa's direction (duh)-Two separate parts feel jarring at first8.4/10

In 'Rashomon', Kurosawa went back in time and used a period setting to tell a simple story about the mysteries and perspectives involved in deciding what's true and what's not. But what Rashomon also succeeded in doing, was underlining the general paranoia and cynicism prevalent in post WWII Japan. In 'Ikiru', Kurosawa does something similar, but this time in a contemporary setting, with a little more intimacy. The protagonist Watanabe's quest to find a purpose in the last few days of his life directly reflects Japan's quest to find a new identity after the war.But having said all that, what makes 'Ikiru' the special film that it is, isn't the discussion it lends itself to in terms of the broader historical context. What makes it special is the fact that 'Ikiru' is a deeply personal film whose themes will resonate with every viewer. The character of Kenji Watanabe is incredible, because he transcends geographical and racial boundaries. Each and every viewer has either known someone like this or is someone like this irrespective of which nation they belong to. In Ermanno Olmi's 'Il Posto'(which is a film that deals with the dehumanisation of people in the growing industrial setting of post war Italy), for a few minutes, the film shifts the perspective from the protagonist Domenico to the older employees of the corporation to underline the pointlessness of their lives. Watanabe could easily have been one of those older men in 'Il Posto'. I have known many men like Watanabe. He is a man who allowed himself to get trapped in the bureaucratic maze. In the scene where we first meet him, Watanabe is in the middle of the shot, while the rest of the shot is crammed up completely with official documents. When the devastating news of the stomach cancer hits Watanabe, we can't help but feel immensely sorry for him. Kurosawa then gives us a insight into the world of this old man. We get to know that he has a son and daughter-in-law who remain distant to him(which reminded me of Ozu's 'Tokyo Story'). We learn that he is a widow and had decided to not remarry for the sake of his son. We see laminated certificates on the wall symbolising Watanabe's slavish dedication to his job for decades. But as he stands at the brink of death, his job, his sacrifices, his life as a whole, everything seems pointless.I really loved how Kurosawa patiently devotes a lot of time towards Watanabe's existential crisis, his search for a purpose, a motivation to achieve some mental satisfaction during the last few days of his life. We see him seek the company of different individuals and try out various activities to initially enjoy himself and loosen up a bit, which he realised he hadn't really ever done. But even then, something always seemed to be missing. We as a viewer also feel his frustration during this struggle. This is why when he identifies his calling i.e. when he identifies exactly what he needs to devote the remainder of his life to, we completely understand his decision, his motivations and we rejoice in our own way for him.The screenplay breaks the narrative of the film into two distinct parts by playing around with the timeline. Although the 2nd part of the film (which to a great extent reminded me of Lumet's '12 Angry Men')flirts with the prospect of becoming a little too didactic, it never crosses that line, because Kurosawa doesn't make the theme completely overshadow the character.It is needless to say Kurosawa's frame composition and use of movement(of both camera and actors) is just imperious. As is the case with his other films, Kurosawa characteristically uses space incredibly in every frame in terms of the visual juxtaposition between the foreground and the background. He might cram a particular shot with numerous characters or objects, but even then you'll automatically focus on the movement of the one character that Kurosawa wants you to focus on due to the beautiful choreography and extremely fluid camera movement.Of course one has to give all the love to Takashi Shimura. His use of a hunched posture while walking, along with his facial expressions make it impossible for a viewer to not fall completely in love with him. Kurosawa uses Shimura's face brilliantly in various close-ups and these close-ups are really expressive. There is a moment where a colleague watches Watanabe walking alone down one of the corridors of the City Hall again with his hunched posture with his back to the camera. This is a wordless, haunting moment and that image of the solitary Watanabe in the corridor will stay with me for a long time.'Ikiru' is an exploration of the cynicism in post WWII Japan, it is a damning indictment of the uselessness of the bureaucratic system(which again is a universal issue), but more so than anything else, it is a touching tale of a man who desperately seeks fulfillment in the final lap of the marathon called life by devoting himself to a worthy cause. It is a film that has the power to make someone care, it is a film that has the power to make someone learn to 'live'.

Ikiru (1952), directed by Akira Kurosawa, is one of the most profound and moving films in Japanese cinema. It tells the story of Kanji Watanabe, a middle-aged, bureaucratic civil servant, who learns that he has terminal cancer and is faced with the realization that his life has been largely spent in meaningless routine. The film follows his quest for purpose in the final months of his life, exploring deep themes of existentialism, mortality, and the search for meaning.Toshiro Mifune's portrayal of Watanabe is nothing short of extraordinary. Known for his roles in samurai films, Mifune takes on a much quieter, more introspective role here, and he shines in it. His performance captures the inner turmoil of a man who has spent decades in a meaningless job and now must confront the finality of his existence. His transition from a passive, almost robotic character to someone desperately seeking meaning in the face of death is both heartbreaking and redemptive.Kurosawa's direction is subtle but masterful. The pacing of Ikiru is deliberate, and the film doesn't rush to deliver its message. It allows the audience to sit with Watanabe's character as he grapples with his fear of death and his desire to leave behind something of value. The film's minimalist approach works in its favor, giving the audience room to reflect on the themes it presents without being overwhelmed by sentimentality. It's a slow burn, but one that rewards patience with deep emotional resonance.The cinematography is equally effective in conveying the theme of isolation that pervades Watanabe's life. Kurosawa often uses wide shots and stark contrasts to emphasize Watanabe's loneliness and emotional distance from the world around him. The contrast between the dreary, gray bureaucratic offices and the vibrant, warm scenes in Watanabe's search for meaning reinforces the transformation he undergoes.The screenplay is introspective, offering reflections on the futility of bureaucracy and the larger social forces that shape one's life. However, the film is not overly preachy. Instead, it gently nudges the audience to examine their own lives and consider how they are living. There are moments of humor and lightness, especially in the second half of the film, which provides a welcome emotional contrast to the heavier themes of death and legacy. The story, while focused on one man's existential crisis, ultimately becomes a universal meditation on how we choose to spend our time on earth.The supporting characters also play crucial roles in the story, particularly the young woman, Toyo, who helps Watanabe achieve a sense of purpose. Their relationship, built on mutual respect and shared humanity, provides a sense of hope and warmth in an otherwise somber narrative. Toyo represents the potential for change, the possibility of making a difference in the world, even if that difference is small and seemingly insignificant in the grand scheme of things.The music, composed by Fumio Hayasaka, complements the reflective mood of the film. The score is subtle, never intrusive, but perfectly attuned to the quiet beauty and sadness of Watanabe's journey. It enhances the emotional depth of the film, especially in the pivotal moments when Watanabe finally begins to make peace with his life and death.Ikiru is a film that encourages deep reflection. While it might not have the action or overt drama of other Kurosawa films, its emotional and philosophical weight is unparalleled. It's a movie that asks profound questions about the value of life, the meaning of work, and the legacy we leave behind, without offering easy answers. Kurosawa's direction and Mifune's performance ensure that the film doesn't merely dwell on these questions but also provides a deeply human answer that resonates on a personal level.In conclusion, Ikiru is a meditative, emotional exploration of life and death. Its minimalist approach, powerful performances, and philosophical depth make it a must-watch for anyone seeking a meaningful, introspective film experience. While the pacing might be slow for some, its lasting emotional impact and timeless themes ensure that it remains one of the finest examples of cinema ever made.

Watching "Ikiru" was an experience that transcended mere film; it felt like a profound journey into the essence of what it means to truly live. As I settled in, I was initially caught off guard by the absence of the samurai action I had come to expect from Akira Kurosawa. Instead, I was greeted by the mundane existence of Kanji Watanabe, a man who has spent decades as a cog in the bureaucratic machine, his life defined by monotony and indifference.The film's emotional weight hit me hard as Watanabe receives the devastating news of his terminal cancer diagnosis. I felt a visceral connection to his plight, the realization that he had been living a life devoid of purpose resonated deeply within me. The transformation that follows is nothing short of remarkable. Watching him grapple with his mortality, I found myself reflecting on my own life choices and the moments I have let slip away in the pursuit of the mundane.There were moments of levity, too, particularly in his interactions with the young office worker, which oscillated between warmth and heartbreaking distance. The scene where he attempts to confide in his son, only to be met with resentment, struck a chord that echoed long after the credits rolled. It was a poignant reminder of the emotional costs of years spent in emotional isolation.Kurosawa's direction is masterful, capturing the stark contrast between Watanabe's dreary office life and the vibrant moments he seeks in his final days. The imagery, particularly the iconic shot of Watanabe on the swing, encapsulates a bittersweet beauty that lingers in my mind. The film is not just a critique of bureaucracy but a celebration of the human spirit's capacity for change, even in the face of impending doom."Ikiru" left me in tears, not just for Watanabe's lost opportunities, but for the universal truth it conveys: life is fleeting, and it is our responsibility to imbue it with meaning. This film is a timeless reminder to seize the day, to find joy in the little things, and to leave a legacy that matters. It's a cinematic experience that will stay with me for years to come, urging me to live with intention and purpose.

At its very core 'Ikiru' is a simple story, albeit an extremely thought-provoking and potent tale - that we can all learn from. We follow Kanji Watanabe (played by Takashi Shimura) a bureaucrat who desperately tries to find some meaning in his life after he discovers that he has terminal cancer. Ikiru is a tragic Japanese film directed by the legendary Akira Kurosawa, and which the screenplay was loosely inspired by Leo Tolstoy's 1886 novel "The Death of Ivan Ilyich."While Kurosawa is perhaps better known for his action films, Ikiru could very well be considered his best. The protagonist, Kanji Watanabe, never seems like a pathetic old man, but rather one of us. As you would expect from a film with such a narrative the film explores themes such as learning how to live, mortality, and family life. Like I said, Ikiru never strays into the mawkish, but rather maintains a dramatic tone throughout.Ikiru is an extremely well-acted and deeply moving tale about a man that is forced to face his own mortality. What I found from watching Ikiru is that the older I get, the more I appreciate it, the more it means to me. It is rightly revered as one of the most human films that you will see, and that is most certainly an accurate description because it broaches some of the most salient and precious lessens of life.

"I can't afford to hate people. I haven't got that kind of time."Akira Kurosawa can craft epic stories of heroism and honor, but he can also convey the same depth and magnitude in a story about something as ordinary as a person's life. "Ikiru" is a powerful and very touching movie, a meditation on life, death, purpose, happiness, and legacy.The first half is somewhat difficult to watch. The main character, Kurasawa, goes through the pain of realizing he only has several months left to live. He has to admit to himself that he has wasted his whole life. He has to come to terms with himself and stop blaming others for his current state and the losses in his life. He is alone and empty, and even the spark that is ignited somewhere deep in him doesn't immediately give him hope and something to live for.His quest to find meaning leads him to start appreciating the pleasures of life and attempt to discover how he can become happy and carefree, just for one day. But it's not enough, and deep down he feels it in his gut. And then, everything changes in the most memorable way.It's that unforgettable scene where he walks down the stairs. A bunch of kids at the top are singing "Happy birthday" and looking at him; then he moves away from the camera, and a girl comes up the stairs, revealing that she's the one they are singing to. But in fact, it's he who is truly born at that moment and has a metaphorical last birthday. This is the moment he realizes that he shouldn't pursue merely enjoying the pleasures of life while he still can; instead, he must dedicate what time he has left to creating something for others. And that will become his legacy.At that point, the movie changes and shifts to a different story. I like how some 2-3 minutes after Watanabe's metaphorical rebirth comes his death and funeral. Kurasawa skips the whole 5 months of his character's new life and goes straight to the aftermath, to his legacy. The funeral is just a masterclass in storytelling, dialogue, and cinematography. I won't say more because words won't be enough.However, I feel obliged to mention how powerful the flashbacks are and how the tension and dynamics between all the present characters slowly but surely shift. Watanabe became a hero for everyone and inspired change, which is something so rare and precious. In the flashbacks, you can see he's barely standing on his feet, he's barely able to talk; he's probably going through hell, but he doesn't give up the fight and keeps pursuing his goal.I haven't cried at a movie since Return of the King. However, the ending, and especially the scene with the swing, moved me in a way that no other movie has. The last two scenes are especially powerful, providing even more depth to the movie's themes and messages. It becomes clear that no matter how moved everyone might be from one act of good (no matter how big), the world won't change, the system won't change, and even people won't necessarily change. In the end, it's a personal fight, and it's all up to you to decide if you really want to make something with your life.However, despite this negativity, there is still light and hope for the future, because every good deed is important and holds significance. Even if it won't change the world, it might change someone's world. And that's the beauty of it.

So far I've mostly seen samurai period pieces from Akira Kurosawa. And the few non-period pieces I have seen, I have not particularly liked. They have been too slow, too Japanese in themes, for me to get into them. Until today.And don't get me wrong, Ikiru is very Japanese in themes, but those themes happen to be pretty universal. That of the meaning of life and why we live in the first place. Kanji Watanabe (Takashi Shimura) is a middle-aged bureaucrat, who has dedicated his entire life to the wheels and cogs of paperwork. Endless paperwork, with no clear goal or even function. Just paperwork. But then he learns that he's about to die of cancer. And this monumental discovery finally jolts him awake and forces him to take a look at what he has accomplished in his life. He doesn't like what he sees.Ikiru's strength is the same that has always been Kurosawa's forte. A really strong central character and a strong theme that is explored through him. And Watanabe just might be one of Kurosawa's best. Through him we explore Japanese society and work culture with quite a critical eye, but the themes and problems themselves are universal. Why do we live? On our deathbeds, can we say we wouldn't have done anything differently? Few of us can, I'd claim.Ikiru is a slow movie. It is also deep, provoking and quite sad. Not for everyone, but for fans of Kurosawa and great themes in general, it is quite worth it.

Most well known and deservingly so for his work in the samurai film landscape, visionary Japanese director Akira Kurosawa was clearly just as at home directing humanly realistic and relatable dramas as he was spectacle and scope with his touching and memorable Ikiru a showcase for the versatility the esteemed artist had.Regarded by its creator as a favourite of his works, Ikiru is Kurosawa at his most restrained as he examines the last few months in the life of dying government bureaucrat Kanji Watanabe (frequent Kurosawa collaborator Takashi Shimura) who upon discovery that he has terminal cancer and only a short time to live, sets out to find meaning in a life he is unhappy with upon reflection of wasted years and missed opportunities.Translated in English to simply mean "To Live", Ikiru is all about its title as Watanabe tries a life full of revelry and excess, a potential close friendship with a female colleague far younger than he and most importantly fulfilment in his job that could see long lasting changes and a legacy to his works that for the most part have not been a part of his over 30 years of service to a role he slept walked through.It's a situation we as humans could all relate to, one's face to face meeting with their own mortality and cause for reflection upon a life one would hope has been well lived and full of love, laughter, friendships and meaning and Kurosawa explores this idea with a deft hand and one full of grace, care and thoughtfulness.Filmed in stunning black and white, with a moving soundtrack and enough memorable scenery to last multiple films (the films iconic playground scene a standout), Ikiru is as strong in the technical department as it is in the narrative components of its intimate yet grand story and despite being nearly 70 years old, age has failed to weary a story that is ageless in its timeless themes and human interactions.It's the type of classic film that excels in every department, from performances of its entire cast, its carefully considered script work and already discussed technical feats, there's barely a wrongly timed step in a film that is moving, funny and memorable and undoubtedly one of Kurosawa's finest moments.Final Say -A key component of Akira Kurosawa's career, Ikiru is a life-affirming tale that has a magic and power rarely found in such human centric dramas. A classic piece of cinema that movie fans from across the world should seek out if they have yet to partake in it.5 games of Pachinko out of 5

Andrew MarvelLiving is the most delicate film of the last year, and Bill Nighy's understated performance as a terminally-ill bureaucratic Brit, Mr. Williams, is achingly memorable. (Subtle sentiment enough to swamp a whale or ban a banshee, I say! ) This adaptation of Akira Kurosawa's legendary 1952 Ikiru does the master justice, both worlds, Japan and Britain, characteristically reserved and private.Having just learned of his impending death from cancer, uptight London civil servant Williams at first goes the way any of us might such as seaside penny arcades and striptease shows. However, he slowly steps into the role of caring human being, starting by taking a young bucktoothed office worker, Margaret Harris (Sex Education's Aimee Lou Wood), to lunch without any other agenda than to begin opening up. He is leaving his "nowhere man" behind.The scenes between them, with her never quite sure if this can be the same tightly-bound boss she's always known and an openness that begs him to watch how life is to be lived. Nighy plays it right by lacking flamboyance but rather as if he were just quietly emerging into life as it should be lived-caring without an agenda. In some ways, he's Tom Hanks' Otto but just across the pond with a little emotional help from Dvorak and Vaughn Williams.While his close-knit bureaucratic colleagues continue to be like their bowler hats--rigid and lacking color, Williams already has a hip new hat along with his new life of meaning.
